conclusion: Understanding principles of electromagnetic induction and how induced EMF is affected by motion in a magnetic field.
A straight metal rod of length L moves with velocity v perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field B.
The induced EMF ε in the rod is given by ε = B * L * v.
The rod is bent into two equal-length segments, each of length L/2, forming a right angle.
The rod is placed in a plane perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The rod moves with velocity v in the direction of the angle bisector of the right angle formed by the two segments.
The velocity vector makes a 45-degree angle with each segment.
The effective length of each segment contributing to the EMF is L/2 * cos(45°) = L/(2√2).
The induced EMF in each segment is ε_segment = B * (L/(2√2)) * v.
The total induced EMF ε' is the sum of the EMFs in both segments: ε' = 2 * ε_segment = B * (L/√2) * v.
The ratio of the new EMF ε' to the original EMF ε is ε'/ε = (B * (L/√2) * v) / (B * L * v) = 1/√2 = √2/2.
